paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the TTR gene and its variants, specifically focusing on the ATTRV30M mutation and its implications in familial transthyretin amyloidosis. It provides insights into penetrance data, clinical significance, and individual patient records.

patients.phenotype: familial ATTR amyloidosis with varying clinical presentations

individual_records.evidence_sentence: Individuals with fibril type A had a clearly higher proportion of wild-type molecules than patients with type B (73 ± 2.1% to 52 ± 5.7%, p = 0.008).

functional_data.summary: The study indicates that the presence of the ATTRV30M mutation leads to a higher incorporation of wild-type TTR in amyloid fibrils, particularly in cardiac tissue.

variants.segregation_data: The variant segregates with disease in families as all patients with the mutation presented with symptoms.
variants.population_frequency: Not available in gnomAD or ExAC databases.
variants.additional_notes: The study emphasizes the importance of distinguishing between fibril types in assessing disease progression.
key_quotes: Individuals with fibril type A had a clearly higher proportion of wild-type molecules than patients with type B (73 ± 2.1% to 52 ± 5.7%, p = 0.008).

The special vulnerability of heart tissue for continued deposition after transplantation and the reason why some patients benefit from the procedure, whereas amyloid progression is triggered in others, are not understood.

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the paper provided clear data on the TTR gene and its associated variants.
